questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with a groin mass below the inguinal ligament that becomes more prominent with standing. You suspect a femoral hernia. Which structure forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal?
questions.solution:
Femoral Canal

  • Location: The femoral canal lies medial to the femoral vein within the femoral sheath.
  • Contents: The canal contains lymphatic vessels, a lymph node (Cloquet's node), and loose connective tissue.
  • Function: It allows the femoral vein to expand and provides a pathway for lymphatic drainage from the lower limb.
  • Boundaries:
    • Anterior: Inguinal ligament
    • Posterior: Pectineal ligament
    • Medial: Lacunar ligament
    • Lateral: Femoral vein

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Femoral vein: Incorrect. The femoral vein is located lateral to the femoral canal.

Option B. Inguinal ligament: Incorrect. The inguinal ligament forms the superior boundary of the femoral canal.

Option C. Lacunar ligament: Correct. The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal.

Option D. Pectineal ligament: Incorrect. The pectineal ligament forms the posterior boundary of the femoral canal.

Key points:

The femoral canal is the site of femoral hernias, more common in women and prone to incarceration due to its narrow structure.

questions.text: A 45 year old male undergoes open inguinal hernia repair. Postoperatively, he complains of numbness over the anterior aspect of his thigh. Which nerve is most likely to have been injured?
questions.solution:
Nerve Injury in Hernia Surgery

  • Ilioinguinal and Iliohypogastric Nerves: Most commonly injured during open inguinal hernia repair. Results in pain or numbness in the lower abdomen, groin, and upper thigh.
  • Genitofemoral Nerve: Injury leads to loss of sensation in the scrotum or labia majora, and pain in the upper thigh.
  • Lateral Femoral Cutaneous Nerve: Injury causes numbness or pain in the lateral thigh (meralgia paresthetica).
  • Femoral Nerve: Rare, but serious; injury can cause weakness of the quadriceps, difficulty in knee extension, and sensory loss in the anterior thigh.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Ilioinguinal nerve: Incorrect. Injury to the ilioinguinal nerve results in numbness in the groin and scrotum but not the thigh.

Option B. Femoral nerve: Incorrect. Femoral nerve injury would lead to more extensive motor deficits in the thigh.

Option C. Genitofemoral nerve: Correct. Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve can cause numbness over the anterior thigh.

Option D. Obturator nerve: Incorrect. Obturator nerve injury affects the medial thigh, not the anterior aspect.

Key points:

Proper identification and protection of nerves during surgery, use of minimally invasive techniques (e.g., laparoscopic approach), and careful dissection.

questions.text: A 60 year old male is diagnosed with a large, direct inguinal hernia. According to the Nyhus classification, this hernia would be classified as:
questions.solution:
Option A. Type I: Incorrect. Type I refers to an indirect inguinal hernia with a normal internal ring.

Option B. Type II: Incorrect. Type II refers to an indirect inguinal hernia with an enlarged internal ring.

Option C. Type IIIa: Correct. Type IIIa corresponds to a direct inguinal hernia.

Option D. Type IV: Incorrect. Type IV refers to recurrent hernias.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old obese male presents with a bulge over his midline that becomes more prominent with coughing or lifting weights. He underwent laparotomy two years ago for bowel obstruction. Physical examination confirms a ventral hernia, and the surgeon plans for elective hernia repair. The hernia defect measures 5 cm in width, located 1 cm above the umbilicus.
According to the European Hernia Society (EHS) classification, which of the following best describes this patient's hernia?
questions.solution:
• M stands for the location of the hernia relative to the midline, where M3 refers to the area above the umbilicus.
  • W represents the width of the hernia, with W2 indicating a defect between 4 and 10 cm in width.

Therefore, M3W2 corresponds to hernia (above the umbilicus) with a width between 4-10 cm, which fits this patient's hernia description.

Key Points:

  • EHS classification provides a standardized way to describe ventral hernias based on size and location.

questions.text: A 48 year old male is diagnosed with a direct inguinal hernia. The hernia is protruding through Hesselbach's triangle. Which of the following forms the medial border of Hesselbach's triangle?
questions.solution:
Hesselbach's Triangle

  • Medial Border: Lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle.
  • Inferior Border: Inguinal ligament (also known as Poupart's ligament).
  • Lateral Border: Inferior epigastric vessels.

Clinical Importance

  • Direct Inguinal Hernias: Occur through Hesselbach's Triangle. These hernias protrude medial to the inferior epigastric vessels and pass directly through the abdominal wall.
  • Indirect Inguinal Hernias: Occur lateral to Hesselbach's Triangle, passing through the deep inguinal ring and into the inguinal canal.

Mnemonic: RIP (Rectus abdominis, Inferior epigastric vessels, Poupart's ligament).

Key Points

  • Direct Hernias:Medial to inferior epigastric vessels, within Hesselbach's Triangle.
  • Indirect Hernias: Lateral to inferior epigastric vessels, outside Hesselbach's Triangle.

questions.text: A 58 year old female presents with a swelling located at the semilunar line just below the level of the umbilicus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Spigelian Hernia

  • A rare abdominal wall hernia occurring along the Spigelian fascia, between the lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle and the semilunar line.
  • Location: Typically occurs in the lower abdomen below the umbilicus, lateral to the rectus sheath.
  • Epidemiology: More common in middle-aged and elderly individuals; slight female predominance.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical examination may be difficult due to the deep location; Ultrasound or CT scan is the imaging modality of choice for confirmation.
  • Complications: Incarceration and strangulation are common, due to the narrow neck of the hernia sac.
  • Treatment: Surgical repair

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Inguinal hernia: Incorrect. Inguinal hernias are located in the groin, not at the semilunar line.

Option B. Umbilical hernia: Incorrect. Umbilical hernias are located at the umbilicus, not below it.

Option C. Spigelian hernia: Correct. A Spigelian hernia occurs along the semilunar line, typically at or below the umbilicus.

Option D. Femoral hernia: Incorrect. Femoral hernias occur below the inguinal ligament.

Key points:

  • Occurs along the semilunar line, commonly below the level of the umbilicus.
  • Difficult to diagnose on clinical examination and often requires imaging.

questions.text: A 62 year old female with a history of femoral hernia is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following is a commonly performed surgery for femoral hernia?
questions.solution:
Surgical Approaches for femoral hernia:

  1. Low (Lockwood) Approach:

Indication: Elective cases.

Procedure: Transverse incision, sac reduced, sutures between inguinal and pectineal ligament.

Complication: Risk of bleeding from the obturator artery.

  1. Inguinal (Lotheissen) Approach:

Indication: Standard repair, similar to inguinal hernia.

Procedure: Open inguinal canal, reduce hernia, close defect with sutures or mesh.

  1. High (McEvedy) Approach:

Indication: Emergency with risk of bowel strangulation.

Procedure: Transverse incision, inspect and resect bowel if necessary.

  1. Laparoscopic Approach (TEP/TAPP):

Indication: Elective or emergency cases

Advantage: Better visualization, reduces recurrence from misdiagnosed hernias.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. McVay repair: Correct. The McVay repair involves suturing the transversalis fascia to Cooper's ligament and is commonly used for femoral hernia repair.

Option B. Shouldice repair: Incorrect. The Shouldice repair is typically used for inguinal hernias

Option C. Lichtenstein repair: Incorrect. The Lichtenstein repair is a tension free mesh repair used for inguinal hernias.

Option D. Bassini repair: Incorrect. The Bassini repair is also used for inguinal hernias.

Key Points:

McEvedy Approach: Ideal for emergencies, allows bowel inspection.

Laparoscopic Repair: Preferred in women to reduce recurrence

choices.text: Epigastric hernias commonly contain bowel and pose a high risk of strangulation
The most common cause of recurrence is failure to identify multiple hernia defects during initial surgery
These hernias arise through the lateral rectus sheath and not the linea alba
Epigastric hernias are always reducible and rarely cause pain

questions.text:
A 45-year-old healthy male presents with a small, painful swelling in the midline between his umbilicus and xiphoid process. The swelling is firm, non-reducible, and has been increasing in size over the past few months. He feels the pain worsens with coughing or straining, though he reports no significant bowel issues. On examination, a small, tender mass is felt over the linea alba, with no clear cough impulse.
Which of the following statements about epigastric hernias is true?
questions.solution:
Epigastric Hernia

  • Anatomy: These hernias occur through the midline raphe (linea alba) between the xiphoid process and umbilicus, often due to a transverse split in the linea alba.
  • Common Contents: Frequently contain extraperitoneal fat, rarely containing bowel.
  • Clinical Features: Small, firm, and often painful; may resemble a lipoma. Cough impulse may or may not be present, and the hernia is typically non-reducible.
  • Complications: Painful due to fat strangulation, rarely life-threatening unless bowel is involved.
  • Treatment: Small hernias can spontaneously resolve. Symptomatic hernias or those with bowel content require surgery, either open or laparoscopic.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Epigastric hernias rarely contain bowel and are more likely to contain extraperitoneal fat, which causes the pain.

Option B) Correct. Recurrence is often due to failure to identify multiple defects during surgery, as there may be more than one hernia.

Option C) Incorrect. These hernias arise through the midline raphe (linea alba) and not the lateral rectus sheath.

Option D) Incorrect. Epigastric hernias are often non-reducible and frequently cause pain due to fat entrapment.

Key Points:

Recurrence: Most common cause is failure to identify multiple defects.

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with a reducible lump in the lumbar region. Which of the following triangles is commonly associated with lumbar hernias?
questions.solution:
Lumbar Hernia

  • A lumbar hernia is a rare type of hernia that occurs in the lumbar region, often due to defects in the posterior abdominal wall.
  • Anatomy:
    • Superior Lumbar Triangle (Grynfeltt-Lesshaft): Bounded by the 12th rib, internal oblique muscle, and quadratus lumborum.
    • Inferior Lumbar Triangle (Petit's Triangle): Bounded by the iliac crest, external oblique muscle, and latissimus dorsi.
  • Types:
  1. Congenital: Due to developmental defects in the lumbar muscles.
  2. Acquired: Secondary to trauma, surgery, or muscle atrophy.
  • Treatment:

Surgical repair: Mesh repair is the standard treatment for both congenital and acquired lumbar hernias.

Explanation:

Option A. Triangle of Petit: Correct. The triangle of Petit (inferior lumbar triangle) is a common site for lumbar hernias.

Option B. Triangle of Koch: Incorrect. The triangle of Koch is an anatomical landmark in the heart used in cardiology.

Option C. Triangle of Calot: Incorrect. The triangle of Calot is involved in biliary surgery.

Option D. Hasson's triangle: Incorrect. There is no anatomical landmark known as Hasson's triangle.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with a history of right-sided groin pain, particularly after lifting heavy objects. On examination, a bulge is palpable in the right inguinal region which reduces when the patient lies down. An ultrasound confirms the presence of a pantaloon hernia with both defects of 2 cm hernia. The surgeon classifies the hernia according to the European Hernia Society (EHS) classification.
What is the most likely classification of this hernia based on the EHS classification system?
questions.solution:
EHS Classification of Inguinal Hernia

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. L1M0 would indicate a medial hernia (M) with a defect of less than 1.5 cm and no lateral defect (L). This is not the case here.

Option B) Correct. The hernia is likely classified as L2M2 under the EHS classification. L2 indicates a lateral hernia with a defect size between 1.5-3 cm, and M2 indicates a medial hernia with a similar defect size.

Option C) Incorrect. M3L1 would indicate a larger medial defect (>3 cm) and a small lateral defect (<1.5 cm), not applicable in this case.

Option D) Incorrect. M1L2 would indicate a small medial defect (<1.5 cm) and a moderate-sized lateral defect (1.5-3 cm). This combination does not fit the description.

Key Points:

  • EHS Classification: Focuses on both medial (direct) and lateral (indirect) hernia defects based on size.

questions.text: During an emergency hernia repair, a vessel running over the superior pubic ramus is encountered and begins to bleed heavily. This vessel is most commonly referred to as:
questions.solution:
Circle of Death (Corona Mortis)

  • The corona mortis involves an aberrant obturator artery that runs along the superior pubic ramus, presenting a risk of significant bleeding during pelvic surgery.

Explanation:

Option A. Inferior epigastric artery: Incorrect. The inferior epigastric artery runs more anteriorly and is not part of the corona mortis.

Option B. Femoral artery: Incorrect. The femoral artery is below the inguinal ligament and not associated with the superior pubic ramus.

Option C. Obturator artery: Correct. The corona mortis is formed by an aberrant obturator artery that runs over the superior pubic ramus.

Option D. External iliac artery: Incorrect. The external iliac artery is located more laterally and inferiorly.

questions.text: During an inguinal hernia repair, the surgeon identifies the inguinal canal. What forms the posterior wall of the inguinal canal?
questions.solution:
Inguinal Canal Anatomy

  • The inguinal canal is an oblique passage in the anterior abdominal wall, extending about 4 cm from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial inguinal ring. It allows the passage of structures between the abdomen and external genitalia.
  • Boundaries:
    • Roof: Internal oblique, transversus abdominis
    • Floor: Inguinal ligament
    • Anterior Wall: Aponeurosis of external oblique
    • Posterior Wall: Transversalis fascia, conjoint tendon (medially)
  • Contents:
    • In males: Spermatic cord (contains vas deferens, testicular artery, pampiniform plexus, etc.)
    • In females: Round ligament of the uterus
    • Both genders: Ilioinguinal nerve

Openings:

  • Deep inguinal ring: Entry point, located above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
  • Superficial inguinal ring: Exit point, located just above the pubic tubercle

Explanation:

Option A. External oblique aponeurosis: Incorrect. The external oblique aponeurosis forms the anterior wall of the inguinal canal.

Option B. Internal oblique muscle: Incorrect. The internal oblique muscle contributes to the roof of the canal.

Option C. Transversalis fascia: Correct. The transversalis fascia forms the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

Option D. Rectus abdominis muscle: Incorrect. The rectus abdominis is located medially but does not contribute to the inguinal canal walls.

Key Points:

  • The inguinal canal is a key site for inguinal hernias.the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females are its primary contents.

questions.text: A 45 year old male undergoes surgery for an inguinal hernia. During the procedure, the surgeon notes the transition of abdominal wall layers into the scrotum. Which of the following layers of the abdominal wall corresponds to the cremasteric fascia in the scrotum?
questions.solution:
A. External oblique aponeurosis: Incorrect. The external oblique aponeurosis corresponds to the external spermatic fascia.

B. Internal oblique muscle: Correct. The internal oblique muscle gives rise to the cremasteric fascia in the scrotum.

C. Transversalis fascia: Incorrect. The transversalis fascia corresponds to the internal spermatic fascia.

D. Peritoneum: Incorrect. The peritoneum corresponds to the tunica vaginalis.

choices.text: Small bite, small stitch technique during wound closure

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with swelling at the site of a previous midline laparotomy scar that has been progressively increasing in size for the past 3 months. He has no symptoms of pain, obstruction, or fever. On examination, a reducible mass is noted, which expands on coughing. The patient has a history of obesity and chronic steroid use.
Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for developing an incisional hernia?
questions.solution:
Incisional Hernia

  • Definition: Incisional hernias arise through a defect in the musculofascial layers at the site of a previous surgical incision.
  • Incidence: Reported in 10-50% of laparotomy incisions and 1-5% of laparoscopic port sites.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Patient-related factors: Obesity, genetic collagen disorders, poor healing (e.g., malnutrition, immunosuppression), chronic cough, cancer, steroid use.
    • Wound-related factors: Infection, wound tension, poor tissue quality.
    • Surgical-related factors: Poor closure technique, inappropriate suture material.
  • Prevention:
    • Preoperative optimization of the patient (weight loss, smoking cessation) and Proper surgical technique.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Obesity: Incorrect. Obesity is a significant risk factor for the development of incisional hernias due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and poor wound healing.

Option B) Smoking: Incorrect. Smoking is a risk factor as it impairs tissue oxygenation and wound healing.

Option C) Chronic steroid use: Incorrect. Steroid use leads to impaired wound healing, making it a risk factor for incisional hernias.

Option D) Small bite, small stitch technique during wound closure: Correct. This technique is actually recommended to prevent incisional hernias, as smaller bites placed closer together reduce the risk of herniation.

Key points: Proper surgical technique (e.g., small bite, small stitch technique, consideration of prophylactic mesh in high-risk patients) can prevent incisional hernia.

choices.text: It is more common in men than in women
Obturator hernia typically presents with a palpable lump in the groin
Pain is commonly referred to the knee due to obturator nerve involvement
Surgical repair of the hernia does not typically involve mesh placement

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent, intermittent lower abdominal pain and recent onset of bowel obstruction symptoms. On physical examination, no obvious hernia is visible. However, there is tenderness noted on a vaginal exam near the obturator foramen. A CT scan confirms the presence of an obturator hernia with signs of bowel obstruction.Which of the following statements about obturator hernia is correct?
questions.solution:
Obturator Hernia

  • A rare hernia that passes through the obturator canal.
  • Epidemiology: Occurs six times more frequently in women than men, particularly in elderly women.
  • Clinical Features: Presents with signs of bowel obstruction. Pain may be referred to the medial thigh or knee due to obturator nerve involvement (Howship-Romberg sign).
  • Physical Examination: The hernia is often not palpable, but may be detected on vaginal or rectal examination.
  • Complications: Obturator hernias frequently present with strangulation and may involve a Richter's hernia (partial bowel wall involvement).
  • Surgical Management: Usually approached through a laparotomy, with mesh repair being the preferred technique. Laparoscopic repair is an option, although reduction can be difficult and may risk bowel injury.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Obturator hernia is six times more common in women than in men, typically affecting older women.

Option B) Incorrect. Obturator hernia is often difficult to palpate and does not commonly present with a palpable lump, as it lies deep and is covered by the pectineus muscle.

Option C) Correct. Referred pain to the knee is a characteristic feature, as the obturator nerve transmits pain along its geniculate branch to the knee.

Option D) Incorrect. Mesh repair is commonly used in the surgical management of obturator hernias, with either laparoscopic or open approaches.

Key Points: Obturator hernia is commonly missed and often diagnosed preoperatively via imaging. Pain referred to the knee (Howship-Romberg sign) is a characteristic feature.

choices.text: Mesh plug repairs are currently the standard practice in hernia repair
Biological meshes are used extensively in all types of hernia repairs
Heavyweight mesh with small pores is preferred to reduce the risk of recurrence
Primary closure of the defect with mesh augmentation in a tension-free manner is the optimal technique

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents for an inguinal hernia repair. The surgeon discusses the use of mesh in the procedure. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the use of mesh in hernia repair?
questions.solution:
Mesh in Hernia Repair

Types of Mesh:

Net mesh(woven/knitted) promotes tissue ingrowth.

Sheet mesh does not integrate with tissue and needs strong fixation.

Complications: Meshoma(fibrous mass causing pain), migration, erosion, and fistula formation.

Mesh Characteristics:

  • Lightweight, large-pore mesh is preferred to promote flexibility and reduce fibrosis.
  • Heavyweight mesh leads to stiffness and more fibrosis.
  • Synthetic mesh: Polypropylene is most common, provoking tissue ingrowth.
  • Biological mesh: Derived from human or animal sources, expensive, and used selectively.
  • Absorbable Meshes: Primarily used in temporary repairs; not recommended for permanent hernia repairs.

Intraperitoneal Mesh: Designed with non-adhesive surface to avoid adhesions to bowel but still carries risks like bowel obstruction and erosion.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Mesh plug repairs have been largely abandoned due to the development of meshomas, which can cause chronic pain.

Option B) Incorrect. Biological meshes are expensive and their role in routine hernia repair is still being evaluated.

Option C) Incorrect. Heavyweight meshes with small pores can lead to excessive fibrosis and contracture, causing chronic pain and hernia recurrence.

Option D) Correct. The best technique involves primary closure of the hernia defect with mesh placed in a tension-free manner to reinforce the repair and prevent recurrence.

Key Points: Optimal repair involves tension-free closure with mesh augmentation. Lightweight, large-pore mesh is associated with less fibrosis and better patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a history of vague abdominal pain and fullness for the past 6 months. He has no significant past medical history. On examination, a large, non-tender abdominal mass is palpated. A CT scan reveals a large retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of a retroperitoneal sarcoma.Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Retroperitoneal Sarcoma

Epidemiology: Rare tumours, comprising 1-2% of all solid malignancies and 10-20% of all sarcomas.

Cell Types:

  • Liposarcoma: Most common type.
  • Leiomyosarcoma
  • Malignant fibrous histiocytoma.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Patients present late due to the large potential space in the retroperitoneum.
  • Symptoms include non-specific abdominal pain and fullness.

Imaging: Detailed multiplanar CT and MRI for staging, tumour detection, and surgical planning.

Treatment: Surgical resection is the definitive treatment. Chemotherapy and radiotherapy are rarely beneficial without surgery.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Radiotherapy alone is not the first-line treatment and has limited benefit without surgical debulking.

Option B) Incorrect. Chemotherapy alone is rarely beneficial in treating retroperitoneal sarcomas.

Option C) Correct. Surgical resection is the mainstay of treatment for retroperitoneal sarcomas and is often curative, especially in cases of low-grade liposarcomas.

Option D) Incorrect. Palliative care is considered in cases where resection is not feasible, but surgery is the primary treatment when possible.

Key Points:

  • Surgery is the only curative treatment for retroperitoneal sarcoma. Liposarcoma is the most common cell type. CT/MRI is essential for surgical planning.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with bilateral flank pain, lower back discomfort, and mild leg edema. He has a history of hypertension and has been on long-term hydralazine therapy. Imaging reveals a greyish, fibrotic plaque encasing the ureters and common iliac vessels in the lower lumbar region. His creatinine level is mildly elevated, and a biopsy shows active inflammation with collagen deposition.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

  1. Aortic aneurysm rupture: Typically presents with sudden severe pain and hypotension, not gradual onset with fibrotic changes.
  2. Retroperitoneal fibrosis: Correct. The development of a fibrotic mass that encases structures like the ureters, iliac vessels, and aorta is characteristic. Histology shows inflammation and collagen deposition.
  3. Chronic pyelonephritis: Associated more with recurrent UTIs, scarring, and changes in kidney structure, not widespread fibrosis.
  4. Pelvic lipomatosis: Refers to benign overgrowth of fatty tissue in the pelvic region, which does not involve inflammatory fibrotic changes like retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Retroperitoneal Fibrosis

  • rare disorder characterized by the formation of a fibrous mass in the retroperitoneum, often involving the ureters and great vessels.
  • Etiology:
    • Benign causes:Idiopathic (Ormond's disease), chronic inflammation, trauma, aortic aneurysm, retroperitoneal irritation by blood or urine extravasation.
  • Malignant causes: Secondary to lymphoma, metastatic cancers (especially from stomach, colon, breast, and prostate), carcinoid tumors, and drug-induced (e.g., methysergide, chemotherapeutic agents).
  • Clinical Features: Bilateral flank pain, lower back pain, lower limb edema, obstructive uropathy, and impaired renal function.
  • Management:
    • Medical: Steroids, immunosuppressants (e.g., azathioprine).
    • Surgical: Ureterolysis to relieve obstruction when necessary.

Key Points: Idiopathic form is known as Ormond's disease. Can be associated with other fibromatoses like Dupuytren's contracture and Peyronie's disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a history of intermittent abdominal pain and a painless fluctuant mass near the umbilicus. She has had recurrent episodes of vomiting associated with the pain. Ultrasound of the abdomen reveals a unilocular cyst in the mesentery adjacent to the ileum, filled with clear fluid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mesenteric Cysts

  • Types: Classified as chylolymphatic (most common), enterogenous, traumatic, and hydatid cysts.
  • Chylolymphatic cysts: Arise from misplaced lymphatic tissue, filled with clear lymph or chyle, often found in the ileum.
  • Enterogenous cysts: Result from embryonic duplications, with mucous content, and require resection of the related intestine during removal.

Clinical Features:

  • Common in adults with a mean age of 45.
  • More common in women than men (2:1 ratio).
  • Common presentation includes a painless abdominal swelling, most often near the umbilicus.
  • Complications: torsion, rupture, hemorrhage, infection.
  • Treatment: Enucleation of the cyst if independent from the bowel. If shared blood supply with the intestine, resection may be required.

Key Points:

  • Chylolymphatic cysts: Most common type of mesenteric cyst.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of intermittent central abdominal pain that lasts for about 20 minutes each time. He also reports nausea and vomiting but denies diarrhea. On examination, his temperature is 38.2°C, and he has tenderness in the right iliac fossa with poorly localized abdominal tenderness. His leukocyte count is 11,500/μL. An ultrasound scan shows enlarged ileocaecal lymph nodes, and his cervical lymph nodes are palpable.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mesenteric Adenitis

  • Inflammation of the lymph nodes in the mesentery, most commonly occurring in the ileocaecal region.
  • Causes: Frequently caused by viral infections (e.g., SARS-CoV-2) or bacterial infections (e.g., Yersinia spp., Campylobacter spp., Mycobacterium tuberculosis).
  • Clinical Features: Intermittent central abdominal pain, usually lasting from 10 to 30 minutes. Associated symptoms may include vomiting, fever (often elevated), and cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Investigations: Leukocytosis (10,000-12,000/μL) is common early in the illness. Ultrasound often shows enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes.
  • Treatment: Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment, especially in viral cases, which resolve spontaneously.

Key Points:

  • Common in children, particularly following viral infections. Differentiation from appendicitis: Poorly localised tenderness and shifting pain are key signs.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male underwent an emergency laparotomy for a perforated appendicitis 10 days ago. He now presents with a high-grade fever, abdominal discomfort, and loss of appetite. On examination, he has localised tenderness in the lower abdomen, but no palpable mass. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated WBC count and CRP. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a localized fluid collection near the right iliac fossa measuring 6 cm in diameter.
What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Intraperitoneal Abscess

  • Common Sites: Subphrenic, pelvic, periappendiceal, paracolic, and subhepatic.
  • Clinical Features: Symptoms: Malaise, anorexia, weight loss, swinging pyrexia, localized pain (shoulder tip pain in subphrenic abscess, diarrhoea in pelvic abscess).
  • Signs: Fever, tachycardia, localised tenderness, possible palpable mass.
  • Investigations:
    • CT Scan: Preferred imaging for diagnosis and guiding treatment (drainage or aspiration).
    • Ultrasound: May be useful in select populations (e.g., pregnant women, children).
    • Radiolabelled white cell scan
  • Management:
    • Abscess <5 cm: Treat with IV antibiotics.
    • Abscess >5 cm: Requires percutaneous drainage or surgical intervention if drainage fails.
    • Surgical Options: Laparoscopic lavage or open surgery in complex cases.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Continue antibiotics only: Incorrect. Abscesses larger than 5 cm require drainage, as antibiotics alone are insufficient in such cases.

Option B) Percutaneous drainage under radiological guidance: Correct. Abscesses greater than 5 cm in size require intervention via drainage, typically percutaneous under imaging guidance.

Option C) Surgical re-exploration with laparotomy: Incorrect. While surgery may be necessary if percutaneous drainage fails, it is not the first-line intervention for an abscess of this size.

D) Increase the dosage of antibiotics: Incorrect. Antibiotic dosage adjustment alone will not resolve the abscess, especially given its size (>5 cm).

Key Points: Swinging pyrexia is highly suggestive of an abscess.CT scan is the diagnostic modality of choice.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a slowly growing, firm mass in her abdominal wall. She reports no pain, but there has been a gradual increase in the size of the mass over the past year. Her medical history includes a diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). On examination, the mass is firm, non-tender, and fixed to the underlying tissue. An MRI is performed, showing a well-circumscribed lesion without evidence of distant metastasis. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of a desmoid tumor. What is the most appropriate management for this patient's desmoid tumor?
questions.solution:
Desmoid Tumor

  • A benign, non-metastasizing soft tissue tumor that is locally aggressive. Often associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).
  • Aetiology: Thought to be hamartomatous or fibromatous in nature, possibly linked to repeated trauma. Occurs more frequently in women.
  • Histology: fibroblasts and plasmodial cell masses, with myxomatous changes seen centrally.
  • Clinical Presentation: Firm, non-tender mass often in the abdominal wall. Desmoid tumors may grow slowly but can become large and locally invasive.
  • Management: Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice. Close follow-up is needed due to the high recurrence rate.
  • Complications: Local recurrence is common,

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. Observation may be considered in asymptomatic, small desmoid tumors, but in this case, the tumor is growing, making surgical excision more appropriate.

Option B) Incorrect. Radiation therapy is not the first-line treatment but may be used in recurrent or inoperable cases.

Option C) Correct. Surgical excision with wide margins is the mainstay of treatment to reduce the risk of local recurrence. Desmoid tumors have a high recurrence rate if not adequately excised.

Option D) Incorrect. Chemotherapy is reserved for unresectable or recurrent cases but is not the first-line treatment.

Key Points: Desmoid tumors are locally aggressive but non-metastasizing. Often associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

questions.text: A 58-year-old male undergoes surgery for a recurrent incisional hernia. The surgeon plans to use mesh for repair and discusses different options for mesh placement. Which of the following mesh placements is generally preferred due to its mechanical advantage, as the abdominal pressure helps keep the mesh in place?
questions.solution:
Mesh Positioning in Hernia Repair

  • Onlay Mesh: Placed in the subcutaneous space on top of the muscle/fascia. Risks include wound breakdown, skin ischemia, and seroma formation.
  • Inlay Mesh: Placed within the defect and is generally not recommended due to weak mechanical support, functioning similarly to a suture repair.
  • Sublay Mesh: Placed deep to the muscle layers in the abdominal wall. Preferred due to its mechanical advantage, as abdominal pressure helps keep the mesh in place.
  • Extraperitoneal Mesh: Similar to sublay placement; also provides mechanical benefits and is a favored approach.
  • Intraperitoneal Mesh: Placed inside the peritoneal cavity but is associated with higher complication rates, such as adhesions and bowel injury, making it less favored.

Explanation:

Option A) Inlay: Incorrect. Inlay meshes are not recommended as they behave similarly to suture repair, providing insufficient mechanical support.

Option B) Onlay: Incorrect. Onlay mesh placement has a risk of complications such as skin ischemia and seroma formation due to skin flap elevation and exposure risks.

Option C) Sublay: Correct. Sublay mesh placement has a mechanical advantage, as the abdominal pressure helps keep the mesh in place, making it a preferred method.

Option D) Intraperitoneal: Incorrect. Intraperitoneal mesh placement is associated with more complications and is now generally avoided by many surgeons.

Key Points: Sublay and extraperitoneal mesh placements are generally preferred in hernia repair. Onlay mesh risks include skin ischemia and seroma.
